(Simplified: Ë¥ù)
Ideographic: A sea shell, once used as currency

heisig_chinese_memo: Eye thought I saw a shellfish legging it down the beach!
heisig_constituent: shellfish, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight
heisig_story: To remember the primitive elements that make up this kanji, an eye and animal legs, you might be tempted to think of it as a pictograph of a shellfish with its ridged shell at the top and two little legs sticking out of the bottom. But that might not help you recall later just how many ridges to put on the shell. Better to imagine a freakish shellfish with a single, gigantic eye roaming the beaches on its slender little legs, scaring the wits out of the sunbathers.
koohiiStory1: Eye thought I saw a shellfish legging it down the beach!
koohiiStory2: Stare at the shellfish, it looks like an eye with legs.
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The shellfish radical and the shellfish kanji are the same! It can be just the shell part too.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: To get some shellfish, all you have to do is hop in your kayak („Åã„ÅÑ) and get some. Shellfish live in the water.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine rowing your kayak out into the ocean to collect shellfish. Imagine the color and shape of the kayak. Feel the spray of the salt water and the taste of some fresh shellfish, right out of the ocean.
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the eight („Éè) eyes (ÁõÆ) belong to the shellfish
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: This odd looking shellfish gets around with two animal legs - one giant leg and one little one.  It does have a healthy looking shell and eyes though.
humanum_full_description_en:
Oracle-bone inscriptions are shaped like shells, and the ancients used " shells " as their currency. Therefore, the word " bei " is generally related to goods and trading. The character "Ë¥ù" oracle bone inscriptions resemble a kind of sea shell . Two short vertical strokes are drawn under the inscription "Ë¥ù" in the inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty. The angle above the glyph gradually becomes a horizontal stroke during the Warring States Period. "Shuowen": "Shells, sea insects. The name of the land is Áåã, and the name of the chrysalis in the water. Pictogram. The ancients bought shells and treasured turtles, and there were springs in Zhou Dynasty. Until Qin abandoned shells, all shellfish belonged to shells. According to Guo Moruo's view, the ancients first used shells as neck ornaments, and later evolved into currency.

The Oracle " Bei " refers to sea shells, or used as sacrifices, "Collection" 5648: "[ÈöπÁ§∫Âèà] Bei Yuqi (wo)." The full sentence means to give sea shells to a woman for some kind of sacrifice. Also used as a gift, "Collection" 40073: "Yi (given) Bei Erpeng." In addition, the word is suspected to be used as a place name, "Collection" 40071: "Wu Zhi Bei".

The inscription " bei " mostly refers to shell coins, which are used as gifts. He Zun: "Yi (gives) shellfish 30 friends." In ancient times, two shells were a friend, and there is no definite number. See " Peng ". In addition, there is the word "shellfish" in the inscriptions, which refers to a helmet decorated with shells (Shirakawa Jing), and a small ding: "shellfish one."

The characters of the Warring States Period are used as the original meaning, referring to the sea shells, "Shangbo Zhushu IV. Yi Shi. "Jiao Jiao Wu Wu" Jane 4: "Qi [‰ø§(brother) gentleman, Ruo Zhuruo] shell." The whole sentence says that the gentleman of Helepingyi is like pearls and seashells.

Oracle " Tony ", " heart " shape nearly two, the Senate " heart " word. As for the inscriptions " Bei " and " ding " are also easy to confuse, refer to the word " ding ".
humanum_short_description_en: A gold inscription like a shell.

Chinese dictionary definition of words
[‚ë†]Ôºªb√®iÔºΩ
["Guangyun" Bogeqie, go to Thailand, help. ]
Traditional characters for "Ë¥ù1". Also known as "ËõΩ1".
(1) The general term for shell mollusks such as clams.
(2) Shells.
(3) Yu Jie's teeth are neat and white. The words "Zhuangzi ¬∑ Pirates": "The lips are like a pill of excitement, and the teeth are like qibei."
(4) Describe the whiteness and neatness of teeth.
(5) Ancient currency.
(6) Refers generally to goods.
(7) The name of the brocade with shell-shaped patterns.
(8) The name of the instrument. Also called law conch or law lily. In ancient times, it was used for festival music, monk Taoism was used for rituals, and sometimes used for soldiers and gathering crowds.
(9) Abbreviation of Bedoro. The ancient Indian Buddhist scriptures were written on the bay leaf, so it refers to the Buddhist scriptures.
(10) The provincial name of Jibei. That is kapok. See "Bei Qiu".
(11) The name of the ancient state. It was built in the Northern Zhou Dynasty and changed to Enzhou in Song Dynasty. Tang administers the two counties of Qinghe in Hebei, Linqing in Shandong and Wucheng and Xiajin counties today.
(12) Last name. There was Bei Yu in the Three Kingdoms. See "Three Kingdoms¬∑Weizhi¬∑Liu Biao Biography", "Biao Yi unites the army to Xiangyang" Pei Songzhi quoted Jin Si Ma Biao's "Strategy."

Ë¥ù

Radicals: Ë≤ù  (shellfish)
Meaning Mnemonic
The shellfish radical and the shellfish kanji are the same! It can be just the shell part too.
Shellfish are shellfish, you know?
Reading Mnemonic
To get some shellfish, all you have to do is hop in your kayak („Åã„ÅÑ) and get some. Shellfish live in the water.
Imagine rowing your kayak out into the ocean to collect shellfish. Imagine the color and shape of the kayak. Feel the spray of the salt water and the taste of some fresh shellfish, right out of the ocean.
